messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Elliotte Harold

> This is unavoidable and not necessarily bad. Some lines of
> code in a system are simply likely to be more fundamental
> than others and a breakage there will cascade. For example,
> suppose you're writing unit tests for the AWT or an AWT-like
> system. Now suppose you break the function that draw
> rectangles. This would break every method that needs to draw
> rectangles, including functions for drawing dialog boxes,
> menus, windows, and a lot more.

Right, so I want the testing framework to *not* run any test method that
depends on rectangle drawing because it's a waste of time. And I also want
the final report to let me know that all these test methods were skipped.

In TestNG, I would create a group of functions called "2d" that tests
everything involving simple drawing:

public Test2D {
@Test(groups = "2d")
public void rectangles() {
// test rectangles
}

@Test(groups = "2d")
public void lines() {
// test lines
}

@Test(groups = "2d")
public void fill() {
// test fill
}

}

Then I have the next layer of tests that takes care of AWT itself. These
tests depend on the "2d" group:

public TestAWTMenus {
@Test(dependsOnGroups = { "2d" })
public void menus() {
}

@Test(dependsOnGroups = { "2d" })
public void buttons() {
}
}

You get the idea.

If at least one method of the group "2d" fails, TestNG won't run any of the
methods that depends on this group and it will mark these methods "SKIPPED".
